text: - Hello and welcome to Community Chats.
I'm Aley Hammer,

and today we're
interviewing Gary Zurnamer,
the co-founder and CEO of Vouch.
Gary, welcome to the show.
Can you start by telling our audience
a little bit about Vouch

and the problem you're
solving for your customers?
- Sure. Thanks Aley.
We're a video collection platform.
What that means is we can remotely
or asynchronously collect video content
from pretty much anyone.
With Vouch you set up questions,

you set up structure for
the person recording video,
you send them a link

and they basically record
answers to your questions,

and then you get the video
clips back into the platform
where you can edit it, share...
I mean, I guess yeah,

the beauty of Vouch is that it
can be used for testimonials,

user feedback, support
tickets, employer brand,
pretty much anything which requires video.

The main challenge is
that video production
is generally pretty hard and expensive,

and for us having one
tool for companies to use

to be able to do it all
is the ambition for Vouch.
- Very cool.
I mean, as a content creator myself

I can definitely see how
useful these tools are.

Gary, Vouch has achieved
a lot in its first year.
What have you learned over the past

12 to 18 months about
building a scalable product?

- Yeah. I think scalable
and video together
becomes a big challenge.

I mean, we started a
little bit naively around
the challenges that video presents.

Especially with Vouch,
it's all browser based.

There's no app downloads
or Chrome extensions,

so ultimately you have to
work across every browser,
every device, has to be fast,
people expect it to upload immediately.

There's all these
expectations around videos.
I think we learned that

you need to meet those
expectations quite quickly

and having a scalable
infrastructure that you can trust

and you know that when
people are recording,
especially if someone's doing testimonials
or publicly facing content on there,

we need to be sure that
we're reliable and scalable.
So that was a big lesson for us.
Basically just that we don't have
to rewrite the codes to do that.
There are tools like what AWS provides us
that can get us there quite quickly

and then we can add our
own layers on top of that.

- Well, one thing that I
really love about Vouch

is that you're so invested
in customer feedback

and that you actually
tailor your products based

on what your customers
are saying they need.
That's really cool.
Gary, why did you choose the Cloud,
and I guess in particular, AWS?

- I mean, I would say
it was an easy decision.
We looked at a few options,

and I mean, for us
there's a level of trust,
security, with AWS.
We work with global clients,

and some of those clients
are big enterprise clients.
From the beginning we thought about
if we could go into any security reviews
or larger enterprise deals,

how does being a AWS partner
or using AWS help us?
That was a big consideration.

It offers an all in one
suite for us to cross video

that we've continued
to build upon as well.
Everything from storage to scaling,
security, transcriptions,
all those things we're laddering on top.

We're even looking at
machine learning and AI
that AWS provides to,
how can we take some of the video elements

and the transcription elements
and produce usable content?
For us the key is having

a pipeline of process and
development within AWS,

and then obviously the
brand name and the security
was a big plus for us as well.
- Thanks for sharing.

I mean, one thing that you
keep mentioning is that
Vouch was really driven to use AWS

because you needed to
deliver video at scale.
What I wanna know is why is scale
so important to you and your customers?

- I mean, I think in the
time that we've created Vouch

there's been something like
10,000 videos recorded,
hundreds of thousands of minutes,
hundreds of thousands of views.

Even though we're quite
early in our journey
we're seeing a scale of volume of video
that we knew would come

but we weren't sure of when
that time it would come.

For us we just need to know
that it works, it's reliable.
That it goes through a pipeline
that we're comfortable with,

and that we don't get the
hundreds of support tickets
telling us people can't record.
Luckily today, I mean,
I guess through the hard work of the team
and a combination of technology
we haven't had that.
But yeah, video's tricky.

We just wanna make sure
it's fast and scalable.

Those are the two things
we talk about a lot.
- One thing I read was that
I think there's been

over 14.6 billion minutes
of video watched in 2021.
That blows my mind.

With video consumption
increasing so rapidly,

what does the future look
for you guys at Vouch?
One thing I really wanted to ask you is,

do you think that your
product will be impacted,
with events starting to be in person again
as opposed to all those virtual events
over the last two years?
- It's a great question.
I think you've probably...

Obviously there's the
traditional video usage
that we see on social networks,
and I think in business

it started to become
more and more ubiquitous.
There's obviously synchronous video
like we're doing now,
where it's a live Zoom,

but we just think that
there's so much play
to go for video within the organization.
In relation to events,
I mean, for us, it's great.
We'd love in person events to come back.

A lot of people used
Vouch at in person events.
So pre, post and during even.
Going into an event,
what we found when it was all digital
people needed to hear from speakers
and get a sense of who was gonna be there.

So they used Vouch to
create these video assets

that they would share
during the event digitally,
but the same thing happens at events,
they want video content to showcase.
They need it between sessions.

We have people at booths
that are live events,

happy to be there in their
swag or whatever it might be,

but they still wanna collect
video from the event,

so we have a QR code that you
can scan and add an event.
Basically you can leave a testimonial

or some sort of video content
for that person at the booth.
We see video throughout the process

but for us we're excited
for them to come back
and we think that is a good hybrid world.

- Gary, thank you so much
for coming in the show.
Your company is so cool.

I'm a little biased 'cause
I absolutely love video,
but if anyone has any questions

please pop them in the
comment section below
and we'll get back to you.
Thanks so much, Gary.
- Thanks, Aley. Cheers.
